security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill providing step-by-step guidance for integrating bodhi-js-sdk into React applications. All 438 static findings are false positives: the scanner misinterprets markdown code block delimiters (triple backticks) as Ruby shell backtick execution, legitimate Bodhi SDK endpoints as hardcoded network targets, and standard Vite environment variable patterns as sensitive data access. No executable code exists - only markdown documentation files (.md) with code examples for user reference.

content.user_title: Add local LLM chat to React apps
content.value_statement: Users need to integrate local LLM capabilities into React applications. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for installing bodhi-js-sdk, configuring OAuth authentication, and building streaming chat interfaces with the Bodhi Browser ecosystem.
actual_capabilities: Install bodhi-js-react package via npm and configure BodhiProvider
Implement OAuth 2.0 + PKCE authentication flow for local LLM access
Create streaming chat interface using AsyncGenerator pattern
Configure basePath for GitHub Pages deployment
Troubleshoot connection, authentication, and streaming issues
Implement model caching with browser localStorage
limitations: Requires Bodhi App backend running locally at localhost:1135
Requires OAuth client registration at developer.getbodhi.app
Chrome extension mode requires Bodhi Browser extension
Production OAuth requires real domain, not localhost

use_cases.title: Build local LLM chat
use_cases.description: Add streaming chat interface to React+Vite app using bodhi-js-react package

use_cases.title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
use_cases.description: Configure basePath and OAuth for static site deployment with custom domains

use_cases.title: Troubleshoot integration
use_cases.description: Diagnose and fix connection, authentication, and streaming issues in production

prompt_templates.title: Basic Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Add bodhi-js-sdk to my React+Vite project. Install the package, wrap my app with BodhiProvider using client ID from developer portal, and create a simple chat component.

prompt_templates.title: GitHub Pages Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure my bodhi-integrated React app for GitHub Pages. Set correct basePath in vite.config.ts and BodhiProvider, add 404.html redirect, and configure OAuth redirect URI.

prompt_templates.title: OAuth Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up OAuth authentication for bodhi-js-sdk. Configure dev environment with localhost auth server and prod environment with production auth server using environment variables.

prompt_templates.title: Streaming Chat
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complete streaming chat component using useBodhi hook. Include model selection, AsyncGenerator streaming loop, loading states, error handling, and multi-turn conversation support.

output_examples.input: Add bodhi-js-sdk to my React+Vite project
output: 2. Wrap App.tsx with BodhiProvider using your OAuth client ID
3. Create Chat.tsx using useBodhi hook for client access
4. Implement streaming chat with for await loop over chunks
5. Run npm run dev and test the authentication flow

output_examples.input: Configure OAuth for development and production
output: Development: Use auth server at https://main-id.getbodhi.app/realms/bodhi with localhost redirect URIs
Production: Use auth server at https://id.getbodhi.app/realms/bodhi with real domain redirect URIs
Use environment variables VITE_BODHI_CLIENT_ID and VITE_BODHI_AUTH_SERVER for configuration
BodhiProvider handles OAuth 2.0 + PKCE flow automatically
Check isExtension and isServerReady using useBodhi hook
Verify Bodhi App backend is running at http://localhost:1135
Extension mode requires Bodhi Browser extension installed
Direct mode fallback used when extension is not detected
Review console logs prefixed with [Bodhi/Web] for debugging

best_practices: Use environment variables for OAuth client IDs and never commit credentials to version control
Check isOverallReady and isAuthenticated before making API calls to avoid errors
Implement proper error handling with try/catch around streaming requests and async operations
anti_patterns: Hardcoding OAuth client IDs directly in source code instead of environment variables
Making API calls before the client is ready or user is authenticated
Not handling streaming errors or connection failures gracefully in the UI

faq.question: What is bodhi-js-sdk?
faq.answer: A TypeScript SDK for integrating local LLM capabilities into web apps using the Bodhi Browser ecosystem with OpenAI-compatible API.

faq.question: What connection modes are supported?
faq.answer: Extension mode via Bodhi Browser extension and direct HTTP mode to local server at localhost:1135. SDK auto-detects.

faq.question: How does OAuth authentication work?
faq.answer: OAuth 2.0 + PKCE flow with automatic token refresh. Dev uses main-id.getbodhi.app, prod uses id.getbodhi.app.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. Bodhi connects to local LLM models through the Bodhi App backend. Only OAuth tokens are sent to auth servers.

faq.question: Why is chat not streaming properly?
faq.answer: Ensure stream: true is set in the chat request and use for await loop for streaming. Check server is running and user is authenticated.

faq.question: How is this different from OpenAI API?
faq.answer: Connects to local models instead of cloud API. Uses same OpenAI-compatible API pattern for familiarity and easy migration.
